description: Here, the reinforcement learning specific data of assume will be plotted. Especially the process during the learning

options.content:
#### Introduction

Here we visualize the results of the reinforcement learning process for the specified units that use a learning strategy. 
Reinforcement Learning is a machine learning paradigm where an agent learns to make a sequence of decisions in an environment to maximize a reward signal. 
The agent explores the environment, takes actions, and receives feedback in the form of rewards. 
The goal is to learn a strategy (policy) that guides the agent to make actions that lead to the highest cumulative reward over time. 
To better understand the agent's learning process, we use visualizations that illustrate key aspects of its journey.

#### How to use the dashboard

This interactive tool is designed to help you gain insights into the learning journey of our reinforcement learning (RL) agent. 
To understand the dashboard take note of the following three points:

##### 1. Division of the Dashboard:
The dashboard is divided into two parts. 
The upper part summarizes the results for all learning units over all simulated episodes. 
The lower part focuses the results on specific units and episodes, which you can select according to the second point.


##### 2. Selection of Metrics and Simulation Subsets:
The dashboard is devided in system wide plots and specific plots for certain episodes, timeframes and learning units.
On the top of the dashboard, you'll find a list of available choices for the episode of the simualtion and a list of RL units. 
Choose the ones you're interested in by selecting their names in the list. The selected metrics will be displayed on the choice-specific visualization area.


##### 3. Interaction with Plots:
The plots are interactive. You can zoom in and out, click on data points to view specific details etc.
In the upper left corner of each plot you find additional information about the depicted data.

If you need some guidance for interpreting the results, you can orient yourself on the follwing steps:

1. Understand Learning Trends: 
Observe how reward, regret, and other metrics change over time. 
Look for trends such as increasing rewards, or decreasing regret. Take note of the evaluation runs, which are done every x episodes. There the exploration isturned off and a "normal run" with the currently learned policies is made. 
While the reward in all learning episodes can fluctuate you should see a clear rising trend in the evaluation reward. the 
2. Examine Policy and Action Patterns: 
Visualize the agent's learned policy and action distribution. Do you see some pattern in the agents actions. Do these patterns make sense with regard to your domain knowledge?
5. Compare Different Strategies: 
For an easy comparison we introduced the ASSUME Comparison dashboard. There you can easily compare two runs with and without learning. Analyse different behaviour of the agents there. 
6. Experiment and Learn: 
Use this tool to experiment with different settings and learn about RL agent behavior. 
It's a great way to develop a deeper understanding of RL concepts.

panels.description: The reward is a measure for the learning agent to determine how desirable (reward > 0) or undesirable (reward < 0) the chosen actions are. This plot shows the rewards averaged over all learning units for each episode.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  episode,
  avg(reward) as profit
FROM rl_params
where simulation ~ '^${simulation}_[1-9]+' AND
      unit = '$rl_unit' AND learning_mode is true
group by episode
order by episode

panels.title: Average REWARD of all learning units

panels.description: The evaluation reward is the reward for evaluation episodes which are calculated with unseen data.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  episode,
  avg(reward) as reward
FROM rl_params
where simulation ~ '^${simulation}_eval_[1-9]+' AND
      unit = '$rl_unit' AND learning_mode is true
group by episode
order by episode

panels.title: Average EVALUATION REWARD of all learning units

targets.rawSql:
-- this query creates a cumulative sum of the reward until now
SELECT 
  $__timeGroupAlias(datetime,$__interval),
  'episode ' || episode AS "episode",
  sum(sum(reward)) OVER (PARTITION BY episode ORDER BY datetime) AS "reward"
FROM
  rl_params
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(datetime) 
  and (simulation ~ '^${simulation}_[1-9]+' OR simulation ~ '^${simulation}_eval_[1-9]+')
GROUP BY 1, datetime, episode
ORDER BY 1

panels.title: Cumulative average REWARD over all units per episode

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
  $__timeGroupAlias(datetime,$__interval),
  'episode ' || episode AS "episode",
  sum(sum(profit)) OVER (PARTITION BY episode ORDER BY datetime) AS "profit"
FROM
  rl_params
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(datetime)
  and (simulation ~ '^${simulation}_[1-9]+' OR simulation ~ '^${simulation}_eval_[1-9]+')
GROUP BY 1, datetime, episode
ORDER BY 1

panels.title: Cumulative average PROFIT over all units per episode

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
*
FROM rl_params TABLESAMPLE BERNOULLI(1)
where simulation ~ '^${simulation}_[1-9]+'
limit 50;

SELECT
  episode,
  avg(reward) as reward
FROM rl_params
where simulation ~ '^${simulation}_[1-9]+' AND
      unit = '$rl_unit' AND learning_mode is true
group by episode
order by episode

SELECT
  episode,
  avg(regret) as regret
FROM rl_params
where simulation ~ '^${simulation}_[1-9]+' AND
      unit = '$rl_unit' AND learning_mode is true
group by episode
order by episode

SELECT
  datetime,
  simulation,
  unit,
  (episode::float),
  reward
FROM rl_params
where simulation ~ '^${simulation}_eval_[1-9]+' AND
      unit = '$rl_unit' and perform_evaluation is True

SELECT
  episode,
  sum(profit) as profit
FROM rl_params
where simulation ~ '^${simulation}_[1-9]+' AND
      unit = '$rl_unit' AND learning_mode is true
group by episode
order by episode

SELECT
  $__timeGroupAlias(datetime,$__interval),
    case
    when actions_0 >= actions_1 then actions_1
    when actions_0 < actions_1 then actions_0 
  end as "noisy_action_Pinflex",
  case
    when actions_0 >= actions_1 then GREATEST(-1, LEAST(1, actions_1 - exploration_noise_1))
    when actions_0 < actions_1 then GREATEST(-1, LEAST(1, actions_0 - exploration_noise_0))
  end as "action_Pinflex",
  simulation AS "simulation"
FROM rl_params
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(datetime)
  and (simulation ~ '^${simulation}_[1-9]+' OR simulation ~ '^${simulation}_eval_[1-9]+') AND
  unit = '$rl_unit'
ORDER BY 1

SELECT
  $__timeGroupAlias(datetime,$__interval),
  case
    when actions_0 <= actions_1 then actions_1
    when actions_0 > actions_1 then actions_0 
  end as "noisy_action_Pflex",
  case
    when actions_0 <= actions_1 then GREATEST(-1, LEAST(1, actions_1 - exploration_noise_1)) 
    when actions_0 > actions_1 then GREATEST(-1, LEAST(1, actions_0 - exploration_noise_0))
  end as "action_Pflex",
  simulation AS "simulation"
FROM rl_params
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(datetime)
  and (simulation ~ '^${simulation}_[1-9]+' OR simulation ~ '^${simulation}_eval_[1-9]+') AND
  unit = '$rl_unit'
ORDER BY 1

panels.description: The accepted volume ratio is the ratio between the accepted volume and the offered volume.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  $__timeGroupAlias(start_time,$__interval),
  avg(accepted_volume/volume) AS "accepted_volume"
FROM market_orders
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(start_time)
  and simulation = '$simulation'
GROUP BY 1, start_time
ORDER BY 1

panels.title: [iP] Average Accepted Volume Ratio for all Units

targets.rawSql:
SELECT
  $__timeGroupAlias(start_time,$__interval),
  price AS "Bid price:",
  bid_id as "bid_id"
FROM market_orders
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(start_time) AND
  simulation = '$simulation'
  AND unit_id = '$rl_unit'
GROUP BY 1, unit_id, price, bid_id
ORDER BY 1

SELECT
  $__timeGroupAlias(start_time,$__interval),
  volume AS "Bid volume:",
  bid_id as "bid_id"
FROM market_orders
WHERE
  $__timeFilter(start_time) AND
  simulation = '$simulation'
  AND unit_id = '$rl_unit'
GROUP BY 1, unit_id, volume, bid_id
ORDER BY 1

list.definition:
SELECT DISTINCT
SUBSTRING(m.simulation, 0, LENGTH(m.simulation) +1  - strpos(REVERSE(m.simulation),'_')) AS market_simulation
FROM rl_params m
where perform_evaluation is False and learning_mode is True
list.description: Can choose which simulation we want to show
list.name: simulation
list.query:
SELECT DISTINCT
SUBSTRING(m.simulation, 0, LENGTH(m.simulation) +1  - strpos(REVERSE(m.simulation),'_')) AS market_simulation
FROM rl_params m
where perform_evaluation is False and learning_mode is True

list.definition:
SELECT DISTINCT unit
FROM rl_params
where simulation ~ '^${simulation}_[1-9]+'
list.description: All units that have an reinforcment learning strategy and hence have the Rl specific parameteres logged
list.label: rl_unit
list.name: rl_unit
list.query:
SELECT DISTINCT unit
FROM rl_params
where simulation ~ '^${simulation}_[1-9]+'

title: ASSUME: Training progress
